title: Kopeshwar Temple, Khidrapur
subtitle: An Architectural Marvel Dedicated to Lord Shiva and Vishnu
overview: The Kopeshwar Temple, located in Khidrapur near Kolhapur, is one of Maharashtra’s finest examples of Chalukyan-style architecture dedicated to Lord Shiva and Lord Vishnu.
Built around the 12th century by the Shilahara rulers, the temple features intricately carved stone pillars, sculptures, and panels depicting mythological scenes from the Puranas.
It is unique for housing two deities — Lord Shiva (Kopeshwar) and Lord Vishnu (Dhopeshwar) — symbolizing harmony between Shaiva and Vaishnava traditions.
The temple’s circular sanctum and mandapa structure, along with its grand carvings of gods, goddesses, and celestial beings, make it a hidden gem of Deccan architecture.

highlights.title: Chalukyan Architecture
highlights.description: Marvelous carvings, pillars, and sculptural motifs depicting gods, dancers, and mythical creatures.

highlights.title: Dual Deity Temple
highlights.description: Dedicated to both Lord Shiva (Kopeshwar) and Lord Vishnu (Dhopeshwar), representing unity of faiths.

geography.intro: Khidrapur is a serene village on the banks of the Krishna River, near the Maharashtra-Karnataka border in Kolhapur district.

details.label: Location
details.value: Khidrapur, Shirol Taluka, Kolhapur District, Maharashtra

details.label: Temple Architecture
details.value: Chalukyan style with circular sanctum (garbhagriha) and mandapa

details.label: Presiding Deity
details.value: Lord Shiva as Kopeshwar and Lord Vishnu as Dhopeshwar

climate.description: The area experiences a moderate tropical climate with pleasant winters and heavy monsoons.

seasons.text: Best time to visit: October to March
The temple looks stunning during monsoon with lush surroundings.

geography.conclusion: Situated on the Krishna riverbank, Kopeshwar Temple remains one of Maharashtra’s most sacred and aesthetically profound spiritual destinations.

activities.title: Darshan and Rituals
activities.description: Devotees perform abhishekam and offer flowers and bilva leaves to Lord Kopeshwar.
info: Daily puja timings: Morning and Evening.

activities.title: Architectural Exploration
activities.description: Admire 108 intricately carved pillars and detailed stone sculptures depicting stories from Hindu epics.
info: Don’t miss the Swargamandapam (open roof section).

activities.title: Krishna River Visit
activities.description: The river flowing beside the temple adds tranquility to the spiritual atmosphere.
info: Calm ghats ideal for meditation and relaxation.

attractions.title: Krishna River Ghats
attractions.description: Peaceful ghats near the temple, used for religious rituals and meditation.

attractions.title: Sangameshwar Temple
attractions.description: Ancient Shiva temple located at the Krishna and Warna river confluence.

attractions.title: Kolhapur City
attractions.description: A major cultural and religious hub famous for Mahalaxmi Temple and Kolhapuri cuisine.

marineLife.intro: Although inland, the Krishna River supports diverse aquatic and avian life around Khidrapur.

items.title: Freshwater Species
items.description: Local fish and aquatic birds frequent the calm waters near the temple.

items.title: Natural Harmony
items.description: The temple surroundings host vibrant flora that complements its peaceful riverside setting.

conclusion: Kopeshwar’s riverside location enhances its spiritual aura.
Visitors find solace in both the temple’s architecture and its natural serenity.

howToReach.title: By Train
details: Nearest railway station: Jaysingpur (24 km) or Miraj Junction (35 km).
Regular trains connect Kolhapur, Pune, and Mumbai.

howToReach.title: By Road
details: Khidrapur is well-connected by road via Shirol and Kurundwad.
MSRTC buses and private cabs operate regularly from Kolhapur.

howToReach.title: By Air
details: Pune International Airport is about 290 km away.

bookingTips.description: Accommodation available at nearby Shirol or Kolhapur with good facilities.
Prefer visiting by private car for ease of travel and exploration.
Carry a camera to capture intricate carvings and temple details.
